708289f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, north on west side fronm 32nd to 34th Streets. The Park Avenue Hotel, originally built in the 1870's by A.T. Stewart as a semi-charitable organization, on the site of the old N.Y. & Harlem Railway round-house (engine-house). It will stand here till 1925.(see Park Avenue).
Compare this with the same view in 1906 (by Brown Bros.), which will show little change beyond better pavement, electrified street-cars, and subway entrances at 33rd Street.
The old frame hotel and bar on the S. W. corner of 32nd Street will not be demolished till after 1910.
About 1895.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.
Neg. # 1506

708285f-a.text:
East side of Fourth Avenue north from 32nd Street, showing 71st Regiment Armory at left.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographer.
Neg #76?

708286f-a.text:
Park Avenue Hotel, west side of Fourth Avenue, north from 32nd
Street.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

708288f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, west side, from 32nd to 34th Streets, showing the old Park Avenue Hotel and the new Vanderbilt Hotel nearing completion. The view is from the roof of the old Fourth Avenue Railway (Metropolitan Railway) carbarns. At the N.W. corner of 34th Street, the first building on that side of Park Avenue, stands the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, later known as the
Community Church, erected in 1867.
To the right, on the east side of the Avenue opposite the Vanderbilt Hotel, stands the 71st Regiment Armory (1893).
1911.

722025f.text:
Park Avenue between 32nd and 33rd Streets, looking west from the excavation on the east of the avenue.
In the foreground the old street railway carbarns have been demolished, and the ground is being prepared for the 18-story office building to be called No. 1 Park Avenue. On the N, E. corner of 33rd Street stands the 71st Regiment Armory. On the west side between 32nd and 33rd Streets, the old Park Avenue Hotel is shortly to be demolished and replaced by another office building. Opposite the Armory stands
the Vanderbilt Hotel (erected 1911).
1925.
Drix Duryea, Photographer.
MAY BE REPRODUCED with credit.

722020f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, north from 32nd Street, showing the new One Park Avenue building, just completed, the 7lst Regiment Armory, and the new Fred F. French apartment houses on the S. E. corner of 35th Street.
April 1926.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

722022f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, north from and including 32nd Street. The new Park Avenue Building, on the west side from 32nd to 33rd Streets, was built in 1927, on the site of the old Park Avenue Hotel. The Vanderbilt Hotel, in the next block north, was built in 1911. Two street cars of the Madison and Fourth Avenue line are shown, a downtown car waiting for the light at 32nd Street, and an uptown car about to plunge into the old railway tunnel, which will be made over for automobile traffic in 1935, after this street car line has been discontinued and superseded by motor coaches.
The Community Church (Unitarian), on the N.W. corner of 34th Street, will be demolished in 1931; and its place will be taken by an apartment building. The new Union League clubhouse will be built in 1930 on the S.W. corner of 37th Street. Up at 41st to 42nd Streets the Hotel Belmont, rising from behind the old Murray Hill Hotel, will be demolished in 1931. At the time of this picture the old Lincoln Bank building, adjoining the Biltmore at 42nd Street, has not yet been demolished; and the tower of the New York Central Building, north of the Grand Central Station, is still under construction.
September 28, 1926.
New York Edison Company Collection.

722024f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, north from 32nd Street, showing the Seventy-First Regiment Armory (1893) from 33rd to 34th Streets, with a little of the new Number One Park Avenue building visible on the S.E. corner of 33rd Street.
In the background the New York Central Building at 46th Street
rises over the Grand Central Station.
March 27, 1929.
F.L. Sperr, Photographer.

708287f-a.text:
Looking south on Fourth Avenue from lPark Avenue at 32nd Street;
east side.
Skyline of lower Manhattan msy be seen faintly in the background.
February 27, 1931.
P.L. Sperr, photographer.

722026f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from E. 32nd (right) to 33rd (left) Streets, showing the New York and narlem Railroad carbarns. The pnotographer is viewing samo in a south eastward direction from: a vantage pont at the N. W. corner of Park AVenue and E. 33rd Street
(Vanderbilt Rotel today).
At the time this photo was taken, this thoroughfare was Fourth Avenue; Park avenue oegining at 34th Street. .hen the present multi story building No. 1 Park Nvenue was erected,this Avenue was extended southward to begin at 32nd Street. In the renumbering, this office building took the number formerly held by Mrs. Bacon at the N. E. corner of Park evenue and E. 34th Street. Behind the board fence in the foreground ran the trains to Harlem, tnru the tunnel to Grand .entral Station at 42nd Street. It was here that the famous Cunnel Gang originated and from which came Boss .rocker of Tammany, a worthy successor to Boss Tweed. In earlier days this was tne bed of Sunfish Pond. The ground slope clearly seen here indicates the size and depth of
Same.
Remaining today (1939) are only two of the buildings appearing here. They are tne 4 story structure seen at the left margin and the St. Stepnen's Roman Catholic Church at the right. No. 197 Lexington Avenue, the first mentioned, is now an automobile garage.
1860's

722028f-a.text:
Park Ave., east side, north from but not including 32nd Street,
to and including 33rd Street.
January, 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
